awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SaTC-EDU: A Case- and Play-Based Learning Module for Cybersecurity and Artificial Intelligence Education for Early Teen Learners
awd_abstract_narration:
Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) are expanding into more aspects of our daily lives as well as key infrastructure. As a result, understanding these concepts and their relationship with cybersecurity is becoming increasingly important both for all students and the nation’s workforce. Providing engaging learning experiences for K-12 learners around cybersecurity and AI education is critical, especially during the early teen years when individuals are developing career aspirations and interests.  This is beneficial at the level of both individuals and the nation, as it contributes to the development of the nation’s future STEM workforce and citizenry. Current K-12 cybersecurity education is largely accomplished through ‘digital literacy’ activities in classrooms or out-of-school initiatives with few authentic programming    elements for younger learners. Moreover, AI/ML do not feature in these curricula even though AI efforts in K-12 schools are separately garnering attention. This case- and play-based learning (CAPABLE) module for cybersecurity and AI education project will address this gap in cybersecurity and AI/ML education for K-12 learners. The project will develop an authentic, engaging learning experience that will introduce students in grades 8-10 to the fundamentals of cybersecurity and its interplay with AI.
 
The proposed effort will innovate in the areas of curriculum and pedagogy to systematically integrate ideas from cybersecurity, AI, and ML. These topics are typically taught separately, if at all, and providing integrated learning experiences in these critical computer science (CS) topics will empower learners in their early teen years. The project will involve development and empirical investigation of a 40-hour learning module—AI & Cybersecurity for Teens (ACT)—to motivate and engage students aged 13-15. The ACT module will be made available for use in cybersecurity camps and/or as an extension to CS and/or AI curricula in school classrooms. The curriculum and pedagogy will utilize collaborative board or card games to orient students to cybersecurity concepts. It will also include an innovative collection of authentic, real-world ‘cases’ related to cybersecurity issues (such as cyberfraud, cyberbullying, hacking, phishing) with which young teens can identify. These will be paired with related, transformative programming exercises in the NetsBlox programming environment and involving AI/ML, which will help build student understanding of ML models and AI/ML techniques including text classification, neural networks and generative adversarial networks. The project team will also design a Cybersecurity Scenario-Based Assessment to assess understanding of cybersecurity and AI/ML concepts.

This project is supported by a special initiative of the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program to foster new, previously unexplored, collaborations between the fields of cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, and education. The SaTC program aligns with the Federal Cybersecurity Research and Development Strategic Plan and the National Privacy Research Strategy to protect and preserve the growing social and economic benefits of cyber systems while ensuring security and privacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) applications are leading most of the innovation in technology today. In the context of cybersecurity, AI can learn normal patterns of data and systems to help detect and protect against malware, ransom, trojan horses, and other threats. On the other hand, increasingly sophisticated abilities to manipulate images, audio/video using “deep fake” AI techniques present new challenges and cyber threats. Although cybersecurity education is crucial for all learners, there can be no cybersecurity conversation today without AI/ML in the mix. Building an understanding of these two fast-progressing subfields of computing in an integrated way makes cybersecurity and AI education authentic to today’s reality. By meaningfully intertwining the learning of cybersecurity and AI/ML for high school students through engaging real-world examples, programming exercises, and playful explorations, we also tap into the potential of building interest in more young teen learners, especially females and students from historically marginalized groups, at a time considered critical for STEM identity and interest development.

 

With this motivation, we designed a suite of curricular activities—“AI and Cybersecurity for Teens” (ACT)—that comprise carefully sequenced activities, presentation materials, real-world hooks, and programming activities—focused on teaching cybersecurity and AI in an integrated, hands-on manner. A key contribution of this project is a novel approach to teaching AI/ML in the context of cybersecurity that focuses on interactive engagement with fundamental concepts usually not introduced until later courses. To this end, we created, piloted, and refined curricular materials introducing complex topics such as optimization (such as the gradient descent algorithm), adversarial examples, and even generative adversarial learning. These hands-on activities were designed to support differentiation for classrooms in which students have limited prior programming experience. Furthermore, we also produced and curated supplementary resources including real-world cases as well as online interactives and games to support learning and engage students.

 

Our work leverages NetsBlox, an extension of the Snap! block-based programming environment. NetsBlox makes advanced topics, such as cybersecurity, robotics, distributed computing, the Internet of Things, AI/ML, and text analysis, more accessible to novice learners. In this work, NetsBlox provides a gentle introduction to basic programming concepts through activities like creating a chat application and scripting the registration of bot accounts. Using the networking abstractions in NetsBlox also provides a natural sandbox to explore cybersecurity concepts like ‘denial of service’ attacks, encryption, and content moderation. More advanced ML concepts are introduced using research-backed pedagogies from computing education research, including “levels of abstraction”, Parsons problems, and subgoals, with cybersecurity being a constant theme. One such example is a decision tree activity in which the students implement a simple decision tree-building algorithm for classifying Twitter bots. After building (and visualizing) the decision tree, the students practice adversarial thinking by exploring how they might fool the learned model.

 

We piloted and refined ACT activities through 2 workshops with 11 high school cybersecurity teachers in fall 2021 and summer 2022. Feedback on ACT activities from both workshops was overwhelmingly positive and teachers acknowledged the importance of integrating AI into the teaching of cybersecurity. While some teachers were appreciative of being able to use programming activities for the early activities (such as cryptography, client-server chat apps, Denial of Service, and sentiment detection in text), they were apprehensive about the depth of programming in the more advanced AI/ML topics such as gradient descent (optimization) given the lack of programming expertise in students taking the cybersecurity class. This feedback guided differentiation in ACT activities so that all students could develop an intuition of how ML models are trained even if they do not engage in the programming activities.

 

Two teachers in Omaha, Nebraska piloted ACT activities in their cybersecurity classrooms in AY2022-2023. ACT activities were well-received by their students, and the teachers provided feedback on aspects of the activities that they or we could do better to improve the teacher experience for incorporating ACT in the classroom. One teacher successfully used several differentiated activities to engage his students with varying levels of programming expertise, whereas the lack of programming experience among his students precluded the other teacher from engaging in the more advanced ML activities.

 

We created a project website (cyberai4k12.org) that provides a description of the project and the work accomplished in this project. Based on feedback from the classroom pilots, we also organized all the open-access ACT materials in an easy-to-use format for teachers on a GitHub website (https://cyberai4k12.github.io/curriculum/), in addition to Github pages for auto-gradable assessments in NetsBlox (https://netsblox.github.io/exercises/), and an “awesome list” for teachers and curriculum designers alike to draw upon (https://github.com/cyberai4k12/awesome-cyberai4k12). We also presented our work in multiple conferences including EAAI 2023 and the SIGCSE 2023. We continue to conduct workshops for high school CS teachers and aim to conduct more of such with cybersecurity teachers as well.
